issues.description: The problem statement explicitly says the 'parents' attribute is a List that preserves insertion order (problem_statement.md lines ~96-97). However, both the template and solution Person.java declare 'parents' as a Set (HashSet) (template: template_repository/src/main/java/de/tum/in/ase/eist/model/Person.java, line ~40; solution: solution_repository/src/main/java/de/tum/in/ase/eist/model/Person.java, line ~40). This is a structural type mismatch: a List preserves insertion order and allows indexed semantics, while a Set (HashSet) does not guarantee insertion order. Students expecting a List (per the problem text) may be confused about which collection type to use and may implement incompatible code. It also affects the intended behavior about "first two added parents" and how ordering or duplicates are treated.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the representation consistent. Either update the problem statement to state that 'parents' is a Set (and remove the requirement about preserving insertion order), or change the template and solution Person.java to use a List<Person> for 'parents' (for example: private List<Person> parents = new ArrayList<>();). If preserving insertion order in the persisted relationship is required, also add the appropriate JPA annotation (e.g., @OrderColumn) to the ManyToMany mapping so insertion order is persisted. Choose the option that matches the intended scoring/tests and update all artifacts (problem text, template code, and solution) accordingly.

issues.description: Problem statement explicitly says: "The `parents` attribute is a List that preserves insertion order." However, both the template and the solution implement the parents (and children) relationship as a Set (private Set<Person> parents = new HashSet<>();). This is a semantic mismatch of the same conceptual entity (the parents collection): the problem describes an ordered List while the code uses an unordered Set. Students will be confused whether they must implement/expect insertion-order semantics, and tests/solution behavior (which use Sets) will not match the textual requirement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the representation consistent. Either (A) change the problem statement to state that the parents (and children) attribute is a Set (or simply 'a collection') to match the provided code and tests, or (B) update the template and solution to use an ordered List (e.g., List<Person> parents = new ArrayList<>(); plus appropriate JPA @OrderColumn if ordering must be persisted). The least disruptive fix is to update the problem statement to refer to a Set (or remove the explicit 'List' requirement).

issues.description: The problem text describes the REST endpoint to be invoked as `PUT /api/persons/{personId}/parents`, but the template and solution expose the endpoint at `PUT /persons/{personId}/parents` (no `/api` prefix). This inconsistency in the endpoint path naming can confuse students when they implement or test integration endpoints: they may call `/api/...` as instructed and not find the routes defined in the starter code/tests (which use `/persons/...`).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the documented endpoint paths with the code. Either (A) update the problem statement to use `/persons/{personId}/parents` (remove the `/api` prefix) so it matches the controller mappings and tests, or (B) add a class-level prefix (e.g., @RequestMapping("/api") on PersonResource) in the template/solution so the routes become `/api/persons/...`. The simplest and least invasive fix is to update the problem statement to reference endpoints without the `/api` prefix.
